metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: District Magistrate of Hooghly passed detention order on May 9, 1973 under section 3(1) read with section 3(2) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicially to maintenance of supplies and services essential to community.
Petitioner arrested on May 14, 1973 and served with detention order, grounds of detention, and vernacular translation.
Report of detention order sent to State Government, approved on May 18, 1973.
Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board on June 5, 1973.
Petitioner sent representation against detention from jail on May 25, 1973, received by State Government on June 2, 1973.
State Government rejected representation on June 4, 1973 and forwarded to Advisory Board.
Advisory Board considered representation, heard petitioner, and reported on July 11, 1973 that there was sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed detention order on July 30, 1973.
Petitioner filed petition under section 491 CrPC before Calcutta High Court, dismissed by Division Bench on July 4, 1973.
Present petition under Article 32 sent from jail on July 23, 1973.

On 31-3-73, petitioner and associates found smuggling rice by Tarakeshwar-Sheoraphuli local train from non-rationed to rationed areas, violating West Bengal Rice and Paddy Restriction on Movement Order, 1968; attacked anti-smuggling staff, caused disruption to train services.
On 12-4-73, petitioner and associates boarded Bombay-Howrah Mail with rice to smuggle to Howrah industrial belts; alarm chain pulled, rice seized worth Rs. 10,000, petitioner escaped.
On 23-4-73, petitioner seen in train compartment with 169 kgs smuggled rice at Kamarkundu, arrested by anti-smuggling staff.
Affidavit by Shri Sukumar Sen, Deputy Secretary, Home (Special) Department, denying blanks in detention order.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was delay by State Government in considering petitioner's representation vitiating detention.
Whether detention order contained blanks filled subsequent to signing by District Magistrate.
Whether grounds of detention were vague.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay on part of State Government in considering representation vitiates detention; representation sent May 25, disposed June 4 (10 days).
Detention order contained blanks filled subsequent to signing by District Magistrate.

respondent_arguments.text: No delay: representation received June 2, rejected June 4; 10-day period from submission not inordinate.
Denies blanks in detention order; petitioner not present at signing, cyclostyled form with ink fillings normal.
Grounds specify dates, times, places, nature of activities; not vague, petitioner not handicapped in representation.

court_reasoning.text: No delay: representation received June 2, rejected June 4; period from May 25 not inordinately long.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot be said there was delay in disposal.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence of blanks; allegation denied, petitioner not present at signing, cyclostyled form normal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No cogent ground to accept allegation.

court_reasoning.text: Grounds specify date, time, place of incidents, nature of activities; sufficient to apprise petitioner; names of associates not needed; no prejudice shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grounds not vague; courts disfavour vagueness only if it prevents effective representation.

holdings.text: No delay in considering representation; detention order not ante-dated with blanks; grounds of detention not vague.
Grounds of detention valid and specific.

statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order to prevent prejudicial acts to supplies/services.

statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition seeking habeas corpus.

statutes_cited.relevance: Violated by smuggling activities in grounds of detention.

outcome.summary: Petition under Article 32 for habeas corpus dismissed; all grounds challenging detention rejected; detention held valid.

key_quotes.text: The courts look with disfavour upon vague grounds of detention, because such grounds fail to convey to the detenu the precise activity on account of which he is being detained.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why vagueness is frowned upon but not applicable here.

key_quotes.text: Where, however, as in the present case the requisite details of the activity for which the order for detention was made have been conveyed to the detenu and he is not shown to have been prejudiced or handicapped in making an effective representation, the argument about the vagueness of grounds of detention must plainly be held to be not tenable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's holding on vagueness of grounds.
